frontmatter.title: Examing the transient and equilibrium CO2 response in the CESM

abbreviations.EMIC: Earth System Model of Intermediate Complexity

children.value: I have run two sets of experiments with the

children.html: 2_22​
2_22​

children.value: Our main first task is to compute the two canonical measures of climate sensitivity for this model:
) is the equilibrium change in global and annual mean surface air temperature after doubling the atmos- pheric concentration of CO2 re
) is the change in global and annual mean surface temperature from an experiment in which the CO2 concentration is increased by 1% yr

children.html: –1^{–1}–1

children.value: ed using the difference between the start of the experiment and a 20-year period centred on the time of CO2 doubling.
First, a quick demonstration that 1%/year compounded increase reaches doubling after 70 years

children.label: First, a quick demonstration that 1%/year compounded increase reaches doubling after 70 years

startingamount = 1.
amount = startingamount
for n in range(70):
    amount *= 1.01

due to the transient effects of ocean heat uptake.
of the fully coupled model by using the equilibrium response of the Slab Ocean .

# For better performance if you can access the roselab_rit filesystem (e.g. from JupyterHub)
# basepath = '/roselab_rit/cesm_archive/'
casepaths = {}
for name in casenames:
    casepaths[name] = basepath + casenames[name] + '/concatenated/'

days_per_year = 365
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
for name in ['cpl_control', 'cpl_CO2ramp']:
    ax.plot(atm[name].time/days_per_year, atm[name].co2vmr*1E6, label=name)
ax.set_title('CO2 volume mixing ratio (CESM coupled simulations)')
ax.set_xlabel('Years')
ax.set_ylabel('pCO2 (ppm)')
ax.grid()
ax.legend();

children.value: Issues to think about here include:
Why is the annual average here only approximate?
Why is there an annual cycle in the global average temperature? (planet is coldest during NH winter)
in the coupled vs. slab model
Much more rapid warming in the Slab Ocean Model

# extract the last 10 years from the slab ocean control simulation

nyears_slab = 10
nyears_cpl = 20
clim_slice_slab = slice(-(nyears_slab*12),None)
clim_slice_cpl = slice(-(nyears_cpl*12),None)

# extract the last 10 years from the slab ocean control simulation
T0_slab = TREFHT_global['som_control'].isel(time=clim_slice_slab).mean(dim='time')

print('The Transient Climate Response is {:.3} K.'.format(float(TCR)))

children.value: climate sensitivity results to compare against

children.label: Some CMIP climate sensitivity results to compare against

children.value: 5 models (left and right columns of symbols) for Planck (P), water vapour (
), combination of water vapour and lapse rate (
) and sum of all feedbacks except Planck (ALL), from Soden and Held (2006) and Vial et al. (2013), following Soden et al. (2008).
ions for abrupt fourfold increases in CO2 concentrations (4 × CO2). (b)
obtained using regression techniques by Andrews et al. (2012) against

estimated from the ratio of CO2 ERF to the sum of all feedbacks. The CO2 ERF is one-half the 4 × CO2 forcings from Andrews et al. (2012), and the total feedback (ALL + Planck) is from Vial et al. (2013).
Comparing against the multi-model mean of the
, our model is apparently slightly less sensitive than the
Let’s make some maps to compare spatial patterns of transient vs. equilibrium warming

children.label: Let’s make some maps to compare spatial patterns of transient vs. equilibrium warming

children.value: Here is a helper function that takes a
field and renders it as a nice contour map with accompanying zonal average line plot.

# The map projection capabilities come from the cartopy package. There are many possible projections
import cartopy.crs as ccrs
from cartopy.util import add_cyclic_point

def make_map(field, title="", levels=8):
    '''input field should be a 2D xarray.DataArray on a lat/lon grid.
        Make a filled contour plot of the field, and a line plot of the zonal mean
    '''
    fig = plt.figure(figsize=(14,6))
    nrows = 10; ncols = 3
    mapax = plt.subplot2grid((nrows,ncols), (0,0), colspan=ncols-1, rowspan=nrows-1, projection=ccrs.Robinson())
    barax = plt.subplot2grid((nrows,ncols), (nrows-1,0), colspan=ncols-1)
    plotax = plt.subplot2grid((nrows,ncols), (0,ncols-1), rowspan=nrows-1)
    # add cyclic point so cartopy doesn't show a white strip at zero longitude
    wrap_data, wrap_lon = add_cyclic_point(field.values, coord=field.lon, axis=field.dims.index('lon'))
    cx = mapax.contourf(wrap_lon, field.lat, wrap_data, levels=levels, transform=ccrs.PlateCarree())
    mapax.set_global(); mapax.coastlines();
    plt.colorbar(cx, cax=barax, orientation='horizontal', label='Surface air temperature (K)')
    plotax.plot(field.mean(dim='lon'), field.lat)
    plotax.set_xlabel('Zonal mean (K)')
    plotax.set_ylabel('Latitude')
    plotax.grid()
    fig.suptitle(title, fontsize=16)
    return fig, (mapax, plotax, barax), cx

# Plot a single time slice of surface air temperature just as example
fig, axes, cx = make_map(atm['cpl_control'].TREFHT.isel(time=0), 
                        title="Surface air temperature in the coupled control simulation")
ke maps of the surface air temperature anomaly due to CO2 doubling in both the slab and coupled models

children.label: Make maps of the surface air temperature anomaly due to CO2 doubling in both the slab and coupled models

children.value:
Tmap_cpl_2x = atm['cpl_CO2ramp'].TREFHT.isel(time=clim_slice_cpl).mean(dim='time')
Tmap_cpl_control = atm['cpl_control'].TREFHT.isel(time=clim_slice_cpl).mean(dim='time')
DeltaT_cpl = Tmap_cpl_2x - Tmap_cpl_control

Tmap_som_2x = atm['som_2xCO2'].TREFHT.isel(time=clim_slice_slab).mean(dim='time')
Tmap_som_control = atm['som_control'].TREFHT.isel(time=clim_slice_slab).mean(dim='time')
DeltaT_som = Tmap_som_2x - Tmap_som_control

contours = np.arange(0., 8.5, 0.5)
fig, axes, cx = make_map(DeltaT_cpl, levels=contours,
                        title="Surface air temperature anomaly (coupled transient)")
axes[1].set_xlim(0,7)  # ensure the line plots have same axes

fig, axes,cx  = make_map(DeltaT_som, levels=contours,
                         title="Surface air temperature anomaly (equilibrium SOM)")
axes[1].set_xlim(0,7)
Lots of intersting phenomena to think about here, including:
than in transient -- especially over the Southern Ocean (the
delayed warming of the Southern Ocean
present in transient but not in equilibrium
Land-ocean warming contrast: larger in transient, but still present in equilibrium
